elements.content: The rapid detection of antibiotics in agricultural products is of great significance. In this work, two stable fluorescent metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), BUT-178 and BUT-179, are synthesized and used to detect tetracycline antibiotics. Among them, BUT-179 exhibits better performance in the detection of different tetracycline antibiotics in water and eggs. The limits of detection of BUT-179 toward tetracycline, aureomycin, oxytetracycline, and doxycycline all reach the nanomolar level. Furthermore, the cycling tests confirm that BUT-179 can be easily recovered and repeatedly used without an obvious performance loss. This work demonstrates the excellent application potential of MOFs for food safety, especially the fluorescence detection of antibiotics in foods.
elements.clean_text: The rapid detection of antibiotics in agricultural products is of great significance. In this work, two stable fluorescent metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), BUT-178 and BUT-179, are synthesized and used to detect tetracycline antibiotics. Among them, BUT-179 exhibits better performance in the detection of different tetracycline antibiotics in water and eggs. The limits of detection of BUT-179 toward tetracycline, aureomycin, oxytetracycline, and doxycycline all reach the nanomolar level. Furthermore, the cycling tests confirm that BUT-179 can be easily recovered and repeatedly used without an obvious performance loss. This work demonstrates the excellent application potential of MOFs for food safety, especially the fluorescence detection of antibiotics in foods.

elements.content: Two stable florescent metal−organic frameworks (MOFs), BUT-178 and BUT-179, are synthesized. These two MOFs can effectively detect tetracycline antibiotics with limits of detection at the nanomolar level, even with the interference of different inorganic salts and the complicated chemical background of eggs. This demonstrates the excellent application potential of MOFs for food safety, especially the fluorescence detection of antibiotics in foods. The structure−performance relationship of these MOFs in the detection of tetracycline antibiotics is also deeply explored and analyzed.
elements.clean_text: Two stable florescent metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), BUT-178 and BUT-179, are synthesized. These two MOFs can effectively detect tetracycline antibiotics with limits of detection at the nanomolar level, even with the interference of different inorganic salts and the complicated chemical background of eggs. This demonstrates the excellent application potential of MOFs for food safety, especially the fluorescence detection of antibiotics in foods. The structure-performance relationship of these MOFs in the detection of tetracycline antibiotics is also deeply explored and analyzed.

elements.content: Tetracyclines (TCs) are broad-spectrum antibiotics produced by actinomycetes. They are widely used as medicines and food additives for animals. However, the abuse of tetracycline antibiotics has led to a large amount of their residues in water and agricultural products. They not only can lead to bacterial resistance but also can inhibit cell growth in the human body and damage biological organs. In particular, as one of the main additives in chicken feed, the negative effects of residual tetracyclines in eggs should not be underestimated. Therefore, the detection of these antibiotics in eggs is very important to guarantee the safety of our daily protein intake. According to the standards set by the Ministry of Agriculture of the People’s Republic of China, the maximum residue limits of tetracycline antibiotics are 3384 ng/L in water, 100 mg/kg in meat, and 200 mg/kg in eggs.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Tetracyclines (TCs) are broad-spectrum antibiotics produced by actinomycetes. They are widely used as medicines and food additives for animals. However, the abuse of tetracycline antibiotics has led to a large amount of their residues in water and agricultural products. They not only can lead to bacterial resistance but also can inhibit cell growth in the human body and damage biological organs. In particular, as one of the main additives in chicken feed, the negative effects of residual tetracyclines in eggs should not be underestimated. Therefore, the detection of these antibiotics in eggs is very important to guarantee the safety of our daily protein intake. According to the standards set by the Ministry of Agriculture of the People's Republic of China, the maximum residue limits of tetracycline antibiotics are 3384 ng/L in water, 100 mg/kg in meat, and 200 mg/kg in eggs.

elements.content: At present, the common methods for detecting tetracycline antibiotics require expensive instruments, such as a gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC-MS) instrument, a liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry (LC-MS) instrument, etc. However, these technologies have disadvantages of a long detection time, a complex operation, and a high instrument/personnel cost. Therefore, there is an urgent need to develop a simple, fast, and inexpensive method for the effective detection of trace antibiotics in water and agricultural products.
elements.clean_text: At present, the common methods for detecting tetracycline antibiotics require expensive instruments, such as a gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC-MS) instrument, a liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry (LC-MS) instrument, etc. However, these technologies have disadvantages of a long detection time, a complex operation, and a high instrument/personnel cost. Therefore, there is an urgent need to develop a simple, fast, and inexpensive method for the effective detection of trace antibiotics in water and agricultural products.

elements.content: As a fast and sensitive detection method, fluorescence sensing has been intensively studied in many fields. With adjustable pore structures, a high sensitivity, a short response time, and a strong anti-interference ability, luminescent metal–organic frameworks (LMOFs) are widely explored for the detection of contaminants, including nitro explosives, veterinary drugs, antibiotics, food additives, persistent organic pollutants (POPs), etc. Under the practical working conditions of MOFs during detection, water is inevitable, but it is also destructive to most MOFs. To strengthen the chemical stability of MOFs, two strategies were used for the rational design of our targeted MOFs. (1) Guided by the hard/soft acid/base (HSAB) principle, we chose high-valent metal ions (hard acids) to construct MOFs with carboxylate-based ligands (hard bases), between which robust coordination bonds can form. (2) We modified the ligands with different halogen atoms to enhance the hydrophobicity of the frameworks, which has also been confirmed as an efficient way to increase the stability of MOFs in moisture and aqueous solutions.
elements.clean_text: As a fast and sensitive detection method, fluorescence sensing has been intensively studied in many fields. With adjustable pore structures, a high sensitivity, a short response time, and a strong anti-interference ability, luminescent metal-organic frameworks (LMOFs) are widely explored for the detection of contaminants, including nitro explosives, veterinary drugs, antibiotics, food additives, persistent organic pollutants (POPs), etc. Under the practical working conditions of MOFs during detection, water is inevitable, but it is also destructive to most MOFs. To strengthen the chemical stability of MOFs, two strategies were used for the rational design of our targeted MOFs. (1) Guided by the hard/soft acid/base (HSAB) principle, we chose high-valent metal ions (hard acids) to construct MOFs with carboxylate-based ligands (hard bases), between which robust coordination bonds can form. (2) We modified the ligands with different halogen atoms to enhance the hydrophobicity of the frameworks, which has also been confirmed as an efficient way to increase the stability of MOFs in moisture and aqueous solutions.

elements.content: Therefore, two hydrophobic ligands, 5′-(4-carboxyphenyl)-2′,4′,6′-trifluoro­[1,1′:3′,1″-terphenyl]-4,4″-dicarboxylic acid (H3CTFTA) and 5′-(4-carboxyphenyl)-2′,4′,6′-trichloro­[1,1′:3′,1″-terphenyl]-4,4″-dicarboxylic acid (H3CTCTA), were designed and synthesized in this work. Two new MOFs, BUT-178 and BUT-179 (BUT refers to Beijing University of Technology), were obtained by the solvothermal reaction of Al­(NO3)3·9H2O with these two ligands, respectively. Both of these MOFs presented good stability in water and high fluorescence quenching efficiency toward different tetracycline antibiotics, including tetracycline (TC), aureomycin (AM), oxytetracycline (OTC), and doxycycline (DC) (see the structures of TCs in Figure S1). Especially for BUT-179, its limits of detection (LODs) toward TC, AM, OTC, and DC were measured to be 19.8, 62.3, 25.1, and 48.9 nM, respectively, in water. Meanwhile, even with the interference of different inorganic salts and the complicated chemical background of egg extracts, the LODs of these two MOFs toward TCs were almost unchanged. Moreover, the excellent cycling performance of BUT-179 further demonstrated the potential of this material for the detection of TCs in foods.
elements.clean_text: Therefore, two hydrophobic ligands, 5'-(4-carboxyphenyl)-2',4',6'-trifluoro[1,1':3',1"-terphenyl]-4,4"-dicarboxylic acid (H3CTFTA) and 5'-(4-carboxyphenyl)-2',4',6'-trichloro[1,1':3',1"-terphenyl]-4,4"-dicarboxylic acid (H3CTCTA), were designed and synthesized in this work. Two new MOFs, BUT-178 and BUT-179 (BUT refers to Beijing University of Technology), were obtained by the solvothermal reaction of Al(NO3)3⋅9H2O with these two ligands, respectively. Both of these MOFs presented good stability in water and high fluorescence quenching efficiency toward different tetracycline antibiotics, including tetracycline (TC), aureomycin (AM), oxytetracycline (OTC), and doxycycline (DC) (see the structures of TCs in Figure S1). Especially for BUT-179, its limits of detection (LODs) toward TC, AM, OTC, and DC were measured to be 19.8, 62.3, 25.1, and 48.9 nM, respectively, in water. Meanwhile, even with the interference of different inorganic salts and the complicated chemical background of egg extracts, the LODs of these two MOFs toward TCs were almost unchanged. Moreover, the excellent cycling performance of BUT-179 further demonstrated the potential of this material for the detection of TCs in foods.

elements.content: The agents and chemicals were commercially purchased and used without further purification. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were measured at room temperature using Rigaku smartlab3 X-ray powder equipped with a copper-sealed tube (λ = 1.54178 Å) from 3° to 40°. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were recorded by Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) using the KBr compression method. The adsorption isotherms of N2 were measured by an ASAP2020 specific surface area and pore analyzer. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out on a TGA-50 (SHIMADZU) thermogravimetric analyzer in the temperature range from ambient temperature to 800 °C under a N2 gas flow (50 mL/min). The fluorescence emission spectra were recorded with a model F-7000 fluorescence spectrophotometer. The ultraviolet–visible spectra were recorded using a model UV-2600 (Shimadzu) spectrophotometer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Reagents and Instruments

The agents and chemicals were commercially purchased and used without further purification. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were measured at room temperature using Rigaku smartlab3 X-ray powder equipped with a copper-sealed tube (λ = 1.54178 Å) from 3° to 40°. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were recorded by Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) using the KBr compression method. The adsorption isotherms of N2 were measured by an ASAP2020 specific surface area and pore analyzer. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out on a TGA-50 (SHIMADZU) thermogravimetric analyzer in the temperature range from ambient temperature to 800 °C under a N2 gas flow (50 mL/min). The fluorescence emission spectra were recorded with a model F-7000 fluorescence spectrophotometer. The ultraviolet-visible spectra were recorded using a model UV-2600 (Shimadzu) spectrophotometer.

elements.content:
The detailed synthesis steps of H3CTFTA and H3CTCTA are provided in Supporting Information.

Synthesis of BUT-178

Al­(NO3)3·9H2O (50 mg, 0.13 mmol), H3CTFTA (50 mg, 0.11 mmol), formic acid (4.5 mL), and 10 mL of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) were mixed and ultrasonicated in a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. Then, the sealed autoclave was heated at 180 °C for 10 h. After being cooled to room temperature, the resulting white powder was collected, washed with DMF and methanol, and then dried in air [50 mg, 74% yield based on Al­(NO3)3·9H2O].
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of the Ligands

The detailed synthesis steps of H3CTFTA and H3CTCTA are provided in Supporting Information.

Synthesis of BUT-178

Al(NO3)3⋅9H2O (50 mg, 0.13 mmol), H3CTFTA (50 mg, 0.11 mmol), formic acid (4.5 mL), and 10 mL of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) were mixed and ultrasonicated in a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. Then, the sealed autoclave was heated at 180 °C for 10 h. After being cooled to room temperature, the resulting white powder was collected, washed with DMF and methanol, and then dried in air [50 mg, 74% yield based on Al(NO3)3⋅9H2O].

elements.content: Al­(NO3)3·9H2O (50 mg, 0.13 mmol), H3CTCTA (50 mg, 0.095 mmol), formic acid (4.5 mL), and 10 mL of DMF were mixed and ultrasonicated in a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. Then, the sealed autoclave was heated at 180 °C for 10 h. After being cooled to room temperature, the resulting white powder was collected, washed with DMF and methanol, and then dried in air [54 mg, 75% yield based on Al­(NO3)3·9H2O].
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of BUT-179

Al(NO3)3⋅9H2O (50 mg, 0.13 mmol), H3CTCTA (50 mg, 0.095 mmol), formic acid (4.5 mL), and 10 mL of DMF were mixed and ultrasonicated in a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. Then, the sealed autoclave was heated at 180 °C for 10 h. After being cooled to room temperature, the resulting white powder was collected, washed with DMF and methanol, and then dried in air [54 mg, 75% yield based on Al(NO3)3⋅9H2O].

elements.content: The as-synthesized MOFs were soaked in DMF and heated at 80 °C for 2 days. Then, the MOFs were immersed in acetone at room temperature for an additional 2 days, during which acetone was refreshed six times. Next, the collected MOFs were dried at room temperature under a vacuum. Before N2 adsorption measurements, the samples were degassed at 100 °C for 12 h on the Micromeritics Vac Prep 061 sample degas system.
elements.clean_text:
Activation of Samples

The as-synthesized MOFs were soaked in DMF and heated at 80 °C for 2 days. Then, the MOFs were immersed in acetone at room temperature for an additional 2 days, during which acetone was refreshed six times. Next, the collected MOFs were dried at room temperature under a vacuum. Before N2 adsorption measurements, the samples were degassed at 100 °C for 12 h on the Micromeritics Vac Prep 061 sample degas system.

elements.content: First, 100 mL of a 0.10 mol/L sodium citrate solution and 62.5 mL of a 0.20 mol/L Na2HPO4 solution were mixed, and the pH of the mixture was adjusted to 4 by NaOH; then, 6.050 g of Na2EDTA was added to the mixture, and the Na2EDTA McIlvaine buffer solution was prepared.
elements.clean_text:
Pretreatment of Eggs

First, 100 mL of a 0.10 mol/L sodium citrate solution and 62.5 mL of a 0.20 mol/L Na2HPO4 solution were mixed, and the pH of the mixture was adjusted to 4 by NaOH; then, 6.050 g of Na2EDTA was added to the mixture, and the Na2EDTA McIlvaine buffer solution was prepared.

elements.content: Then, 20.0 g of a well-shaken egg sample was placed in a 150 mL centrifuge tube; 30 mL of a Na2EDTA McIlvaine buffer solution was added, and the mixture was vortexed for 1 min. Then, 70 mL of an acetonitrile solution was added. Then, the mixture was vibrated for 10 min. After that, the tube was centrifuged for 5 min at 9000 rpm, and 40 mL of the supernatant was taken and filtered. The filtrate was collected and dried with nitrogen at 40 °C.
elements.clean_text: Then, 20.0 g of a well-shaken egg sample was placed in a 150 mL centrifuge tube; 30 mL of a Na2EDTA McIlvaine buffer solution was added, and the mixture was vortexed for 1 min. Then, 70 mL of an acetonitrile solution was added. Then, the mixture was vibrated for 10 min. After that, the tube was centrifuged for 5 min at 9000 rpm, and 40 mL of the supernatant was taken and filtered. The filtrate was collected and dried with nitrogen at 40 °C.

elements.content: Five milligrams of activated BUT-178 or BUT-179 was ground and added to a glass vial with 20 mL of deionized water. The mixture was ultrasonicated for ∼20 min to form a stable suspension, and 1 mL of the suspension was placed in a cuvette. The fluorescence spectra of MOFs were recorded in situ by a fluorescence spectrophotometer with 280 nm excitation, and then the fluorescence intensity of MOFs was recorded after the incremental addition of a freshly prepared analyte solution (100 ppm). The operation method of the fluorescence detection test of TCs in solutions of egg extracts is the same as that in water.
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescence Measurements

Five milligrams of activated BUT-178 or BUT-179 was ground and added to a glass vial with 20 mL of deionized water. The mixture was ultrasonicated for ~20 min to form a stable suspension, and 1 mL of the suspension was placed in a cuvette. The fluorescence spectra of MOFs were recorded in situ by a fluorescence spectrophotometer with 280 nm excitation, and then the fluorescence intensity of MOFs was recorded after the incremental addition of a freshly prepared analyte solution (100 ppm). The operation method of the fluorescence detection test of TCs in solutions of egg extracts is the same as that in water.

elements.content: After measurement, the suspension of MOF was centrifuged to remove the supernatant. The white powder was washed with methanol several times and then dried at room temperature under a vacuum for 3 h. The recovered samples were reused for the detection of tetracycline in the solutions of egg extracts again.
elements.clean_text:
Cycling Tests

After measurement, the suspension of MOF was centrifuged to remove the supernatant. The white powder was washed with methanol several times and then dried at room temperature under a vacuum for 3 h. The recovered samples were reused for the detection of tetracycline in the solutions of egg extracts again.

elements.content: As reported in previous work, the modification of hydrophobic functional groups could significantly improve the stability of MOFs. In this work, two novel ligands, 5′-(4-carboxyphenyl)-2′,4′,6′-trifluoro­[1,1′:3′,1″-terphenyl]-4,4″-dicarboxylic acid (H3CTFTA) and 5′-(4-carboxyphenyl)-2′,4′,6′-trichloro­[1,1′:3′,1″-terphenyl]-4,4″-dicarboxylic acid (H3CTCTA), were synthesized by introducing fluorine and chlorine atoms on the ligand (a). Two new MOFs, named BUT-178 and BUT-179, were synthesized by solvothermal reaction of these two ligands with Al­(NO3)3·9H2O. As shown in , the PXRD patterns of BUT-178 and BUT-179 resemble the pattern of CAU-4, confirming they are isostructural to CAU-4. CAU-4 was first reported by Stock’s group in 2012. It is constructed by Al3+ ions and tritoptic BTB3– (BTB = 1,3,5-benzenetrisbenzoate). As shown in b, the octahedrally coordinated Al3+ ions are bridged by carboxylate groups of the ligands to form one-dimensional chains. The obtained three-dimensional (3D) framework exhibits hexagonal channels with a diameter of ∼1 nm.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Crystal Structure of MOFs

As reported in previous work, the modification of hydrophobic functional groups could significantly improve the stability of MOFs. In this work, two novel ligands, 5'-(4-carboxyphenyl)-2',4',6'-trifluoro[1,1':3',1"-terphenyl]-4,4"-dicarboxylic acid (H3CTFTA) and 5'-(4-carboxyphenyl)-2',4',6'-trichloro[1,1':3',1"-terphenyl]-4,4"-dicarboxylic acid (H3CTCTA), were synthesized by introducing fluorine and chlorine atoms on the ligand (a). Two new MOFs, named BUT-178 and BUT-179, were synthesized by solvothermal reaction of these two ligands with Al(NO3)3⋅9H2O. As shown in , the PXRD patterns of BUT-178 and BUT-179 resemble the pattern of CAU-4, confirming they are isostructural to CAU-4. CAU-4 was first reported by Stock's group in 2012. It is constructed by Al3+ ions and tritoptic BTB3- (BTB = 1,3,5-benzenetrisbenzoate). As shown in b, the octahedrally coordinated Al3+ ions are bridged by carboxylate groups of the ligands to form one-dimensional chains. The obtained three-dimensional (3D) framework exhibits hexagonal channels with a diameter of ~1 nm.

elements.content: (a) Molecular structures of H3CTFTA and H3CTCTA. (b) Inorganic chains of BUT-178 and BUT-179 with octahedrally coordinated Al3+ ions. (c) 3D frameworks of BUT-178 and BUT-179 with one-dimensional channels along the c axis (H atoms omitted for the sake of clarity; color code: Al, blue; C, black; O, red; F or Cl, green).
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Molecular structures of H3CTFTA and H3CTCTA. (b) Inorganic chains of BUT-178 and BUT-179 with octahedrally coordinated Al3+ ions. (c) 3D frameworks of BUT-178 and BUT-179 with one-dimensional channels along the c axis (H atoms omitted for the sake of clarity; color code: Al, blue; C, black; O, red; F or Cl, green).

elements.content: PXRD patterns of (a) BUT-178 and (b) BUT-179 before and after their treatment with water, a HCl aqueous solution (pH = 2), and a NaOH aqueous solution (pH = 10) in comparison with the simulated PXRD pattern of CAU-4. (c) N2 isotherms of BUT-178 and BUT-179 at 77 K.
elements.clean_text: 2  PXRD patterns of (a) BUT-178 and (b) BUT-179 before and after their treatment with water, a HCl aqueous solution (pH = 2), and a NaOH aqueous solution (pH = 10) in comparison with the simulated PXRD pattern of CAU-4. (c) N2 isotherms of BUT-178 and BUT-179 at 77 K.

elements.content: As shown in panels a and b of , the PXRD patterns of BUT-178 and BUT-179, respectively, are consistent with those of the pristine samples after their treatment with water, dilute acid (pH = 2), and base (pH = 10) solutions for 24 h, indicating the good stability of these two MOFs. As shown in c, the N2 adsorption isotherms of these two MOFs exhibit type I adsorption behavior. The N2 uptake levels of BUT-178 and BUT-179 are ∼478 and ∼466 cm3 (STP) g–1, respectively, and the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface areas are ∼1370 and ∼1443 m2/g, respectively. The pore sizes of BUT-178 and BUT-179 are estimated to be ∼11.5 and ∼11.9 Å, respectively, which are calculated by the density functional theory (DFT) method (Figure S3). These pores should be large enough to accommodate TC molecules, which was further confirmed by the adsorption tests of TCs in these two MOFs (Figure S18). The large channel sizes of BUT-178 and BUT-179 could make the fluorophores on the inner surface areas accessible to TCs and improve the sensitivity of the MOFs to these analytes. The TGA curves showed that the decomposition temperatures of BUT-178 and BUT-179 are >400 °C (Figure S4), demonstrating the high thermal stability of these two MOFs.
elements.clean_text: As shown in panels a and b of , the PXRD patterns of BUT-178 and BUT-179, respectively, are consistent with those of the pristine samples after their treatment with water, dilute acid (pH = 2), and base (pH = 10) solutions for 24 h, indicating the good stability of these two MOFs. As shown in c, the N2 adsorption isotherms of these two MOFs exhibit type I adsorption behavior. The N2 uptake levels of BUT-178 and BUT-179 are ~478 and ~466 cm3 (STP) g-1, respectively, and the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface areas are ~1370 and ~1443 m2/g, respectively. The pore sizes of BUT-178 and BUT-179 are estimated to be ~11.5 and ~11.9 Å, respectively, which are calculated by the density functional theory (DFT) method (Figure S3). These pores should be large enough to accommodate TC molecules, which was further confirmed by the adsorption tests of TCs in these two MOFs (Figure S18). The large channel sizes of BUT-178 and BUT-179 could make the fluorophores on the inner surface areas accessible to TCs and improve the sensitivity of the MOFs to these analytes. The TGA curves showed that the decomposition temperatures of BUT-178 and BUT-179 are >400 °C (Figure S4), demonstrating the high thermal stability of these two MOFs.

elements.content: The emission peaks of BUT-178 and BUT-179 are around 365 nm with 280 nm excitation. Before the fluorescence titration experiments were performed, the stability of MOF suspensions should be explored first. It is well-known that the ζ potential is greatly significant for the evaluation of the stability of suspension systems. Typically, a higher value of ζ potential (positive or negative) suggests the higher resistance of the system against aggregation. The ζ potentials of BUT-178 and BUT-179 suspensions in water were recorded as −37 and −40 mV, respectively, indicating their excellent dispersion stability. Moreover, the fluorescence of BUT-178 and BUT-179 suspensions remained unchanged for 120 min, which further confirmed the good stability of their suspensions (Figure S5).
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescence Detection of Tetracyclines

The emission peaks of BUT-178 and BUT-179 are around 365 nm with 280 nm excitation. Before the fluorescence titration experiments were performed, the stability of MOF suspensions should be explored first. It is well-known that the ζ potential is greatly significant for the evaluation of the stability of suspension systems. Typically, a higher value of ζ potential (positive or negative) suggests the higher resistance of the system against aggregation. The ζ potentials of BUT-178 and BUT-179 suspensions in water were recorded as -37 and -40 mV, respectively, indicating their excellent dispersion stability. Moreover, the fluorescence of BUT-178 and BUT-179 suspensions remained unchanged for 120 min, which further confirmed the good stability of their suspensions (Figure S5).

elements.content: To explore the detection performance of two MOFs toward tetracycline antibiotics, fluorescence quenching titrations were performed. First, the initial fluorescence spectra of BUT-178 and BUT-179 suspensions were recorded. Then, the fluorescence changes of the suspensions were recorded with the incremental addition of the solutions of tetracycline antibiotics. Compared with BUT-178, BUT-179 exhibited better detection performance in water (Figures S8 and S11).
elements.clean_text: To explore the detection performance of two MOFs toward tetracycline antibiotics, fluorescence quenching titrations were performed. First, the initial fluorescence spectra of BUT-178 and BUT-179 suspensions were recorded. Then, the fluorescence changes of the suspensions were recorded with the incremental addition of the solutions of tetracycline antibiotics. Compared with BUT-178, BUT-179 exhibited better detection performance in water (Figures S8 and S11).

elements.content: As we mentioned above, detecting residues of TCs in eggs is greatly important for guaranteeing food safety. In this work, eggs were purchased from a local market and used to evaluate the practical application capabilities of BUT-178 and BUT-179. Thus, the fluorescence quenching titrations of these two MOFs toward TCs were also performed in the solutions of egg extracts. As shown in , tetracycline (TC), aureomycin (AM), oxytetracycline (OTC), and doxycycline (DC) can effectively quench the fluorescence of MOFs. The quenching efficiencies of TC, AM, OTC, and DC can reach 95.2%, 87.1%, 95.1%, and 87.4% for BUT-178 and 98.7%, 95.2%, 98.0%, and 96.8% for BUT-179, respectively, when the concentrations of the antibiotics reach 100 ppm ( and Figure S7).
elements.clean_text: As we mentioned above, detecting residues of TCs in eggs is greatly important for guaranteeing food safety. In this work, eggs were purchased from a local market and used to evaluate the practical application capabilities of BUT-178 and BUT-179. Thus, the fluorescence quenching titrations of these two MOFs toward TCs were also performed in the solutions of egg extracts. As shown in , tetracycline (TC), aureomycin (AM), oxytetracycline (OTC), and doxycycline (DC) can effectively quench the fluorescence of MOFs. The quenching efficiencies of TC, AM, OTC, and DC can reach 95.2%, 87.1%, 95.1%, and 87.4% for BUT-178 and 98.7%, 95.2%, 98.0%, and 96.8% for BUT-179, respectively, when the concentrations of the antibiotics reach 100 ppm ( and Figure S7).

elements.content: Emission spectra of BUT-179 dispersed in egg extracts upon incremental addition of 500 μL (100 ppm) of aqueous solutions of (a) AM, (b) DC, (c) OTC, and (d) TC. (e) Quenching efficiencies of BUT-178 and BUT-179 toward different TCs (100 ppm).
elements.clean_text: 3  Emission spectra of BUT-179 dispersed in egg extracts upon incremental addition of 500 μL (100 ppm) of aqueous solutions of (a) AM, (b) DC, (c) OTC, and (d) TC. (e) Quenching efficiencies of BUT-178 and BUT-179 toward different TCs (100 ppm).

elements.content: Fluorescence quenching was quantitatively fitted with the Stern–Volmer (SV) equation (I 0/I = 1 + K sv[Q]) to better understand the relationship between the concentration of TCs and the fluorescence intensity of MOF suspensions, where I 0 and I are the fluorescence intensities of the MOF suspensions before and after addition of TCs, respectively, K sv is the quenching constant (inverse molar), and [Q] is the molar concentration of the TCs. The SV curves of TCs were linear in a low concentration range (0–100 μL addition of solutions of TCs) (Figures S9, S10, S12, and S13), and the K sv values of TCs on two MOFs were calculated accordingly. As shown in Tables S1 and S2, the K sv values of TCs on BUT-178 are 7.86 × 104 M–1 for TC, 5.76 × 104 M–1 for AM, 8.29 × 104 M–1 for OTC, and 4.78 × 104 M–1 for DC in the solutions with egg extracts. The corresponding K sv values of TCs on BUT-179 are 3.63 × 105 M–1 for TC, 1.15 × 105 M–1 for AM, 2.96 × 105 M–1 for OTC, and 1.63 × 105 M–1 for DC. The detection limits (3S b/K sv, where S b is the standard deviation of three blank solution fluorescence tests) of BUT-179 toward TC, AM, OTC, and DC are 19.8, 62.3, 25.1, and 48.9 nM in water and 20.4, 65.2, 25.4, and 46.0 nM in the solutions with egg extracts, respectively. These results demonstrated the complicated chemical background of egg extracts negligibly interfered with detection (Tables S1 and S2). The LODs of BUT-179 toward TCs are lower than the maximum residue levels of TCs in eggs and comparable to those of reported MOFs (Table S3), demonstrating the excellent detection performance of BUT-179 toward TCs. In addition, to evaluate the anti-interference ability of BUT-179 toward inorganic salts, the fluorescence titration experiments were carried out under the coexistence of various metal ions (Figures S14–S17), such as Na2SO4, Mg­(NO3)2, CaCl2, and ZnCl2. The experimental results showed that metal ions have a negligible effect on the detection performance of BUT-179, which further proved the good anti-interference performance of BUT-179.
elements.clean_text: Fluorescence quenching was quantitatively fitted with the Stern-Volmer (SV) equation (I 0/I = 1 + K sv[Q]) to better understand the relationship between the concentration of TCs and the fluorescence intensity of MOF suspensions, where I 0 and I are the fluorescence intensities of the MOF suspensions before and after addition of TCs, respectively, K sv is the quenching constant (inverse molar), and [Q] is the molar concentration of the TCs. The SV curves of TCs were linear in a low concentration range (0-100 μL addition of solutions of TCs) (Figures S9, S10, S12, and S13), and the K sv values of TCs on two MOFs were calculated accordingly. As shown in Tables S1 and S2, the K sv values of TCs on BUT-178 are 7.86 × 104 M-1 for TC, 5.76 × 104 M-1 for AM, 8.29 × 104 M-1 for OTC, and 4.78 × 104 M-1 for DC in the solutions with egg extracts. The corresponding K sv values of TCs on BUT-179 are 3.63 × 105 M-1 for TC, 1.15 × 105 M-1 for AM, 2.96 × 105 M-1 for OTC, and 1.63 × 105 M-1 for DC. The detection limits (3S b/K sv, where S b is the standard deviation of three blank solution fluorescence tests) of BUT-179 toward TC, AM, OTC, and DC are 19.8, 62.3, 25.1, and 48.9 nM in water and 20.4, 65.2, 25.4, and 46.0 nM in the solutions with egg extracts, respectively. These results demonstrated the complicated chemical background of egg extracts negligibly interfered with detection (Tables S1 and S2). The LODs of BUT-179 toward TCs are lower than the maximum residue levels of TCs in eggs and comparable to those of reported MOFs (Table S3), demonstrating the excellent detection performance of BUT-179 toward TCs. In addition, to evaluate the anti-interference ability of BUT-179 toward inorganic salts, the fluorescence titration experiments were carried out under the coexistence of various metal ions (Figures S14-S17), such as Na2SO4, Mg(NO3)2, CaCl2, and ZnCl2. The experimental results showed that metal ions have a negligible effect on the detection performance of BUT-179, which further proved the good anti-interference performance of BUT-179.

elements.content: Fluorescence quenching mechanisms generally can be categorized into three types: fluorescence resonance energy transfer (FRET), inner filter effect (IFE), and photoinduced electron transfer (PET). FRET occurs when the absorption band of the analyte overlaps with the emission band of the fluorophore, which fits the situations of TCs and BUT-178 and BUT-179 (a), indicating the existence of FRET from MOF to TCs. Furthermore, the absorption bands of the analytes and the two MOFs overlap at ∼280 nm (b). Therefore, there also might be a competition of excitation between the TCs and MOFs, which leads to the IFE in the fluorescence quenching of MOFs. To determine whether there is a PET process during the sensing, the energy levels of the lowest unoccupied molecular orbitals (LUMOs) of the MOFs and the TCs were calculated by density functional theory (DFT) methods on B3LYP/6-31G* with Materials Studio. Except for DC, the energies of LUMOs in OTC, AM, and TC are lower than that in BUT-178, and the energy of LUMO in BUT-179 is higher than all of those in TCs (Table S4), indicating the possible electron transfer from the excited state of MOFs to TCs, except between BUT-178 and DC. However, the LUMO energy of BUT-179 is higher than that of BUT-178, and it is more likely to transfer electrons from BUT-179 to TCs in the excited state. This is proposed to be one explanation for the better detection performance of BUT-179 over BUT-178. With the synergistic effect of PET, FRET, and IFE during the sensing process, both of these MOFs exhibited good performance in the detection of TCs.
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescence Detection Mechanism of Tetracyclines

Fluorescence quenching mechanisms generally can be categorized into three types: fluorescence resonance energy transfer (FRET), inner filter effect (IFE), and photoinduced electron transfer (PET). FRET occurs when the absorption band of the analyte overlaps with the emission band of the fluorophore, which fits the situations of TCs and BUT-178 and BUT-179 (a), indicating the existence of FRET from MOF to TCs. Furthermore, the absorption bands of the analytes and the two MOFs overlap at ~280 nm (b). Therefore, there also might be a competition of excitation between the TCs and MOFs, which leads to the IFE in the fluorescence quenching of MOFs. To determine whether there is a PET process during the sensing, the energy levels of the lowest unoccupied molecular orbitals (LUMOs) of the MOFs and the TCs were calculated by density functional theory (DFT) methods on B3LYP/6-31G* with Materials Studio. Except for DC, the energies of LUMOs in OTC, AM, and TC are lower than that in BUT-178, and the energy of LUMO in BUT-179 is higher than all of those in TCs (Table S4), indicating the possible electron transfer from the excited state of MOFs to TCs, except between BUT-178 and DC. However, the LUMO energy of BUT-179 is higher than that of BUT-178, and it is more likely to transfer electrons from BUT-179 to TCs in the excited state. This is proposed to be one explanation for the better detection performance of BUT-179 over BUT-178. With the synergistic effect of PET, FRET, and IFE during the sensing process, both of these MOFs exhibited good performance in the detection of TCs.

elements.content: Absorption spectra of TCs and (a) emission and (b) excitation spectra of BUT-178 and BUT-179 in solutions of egg extracts.
elements.clean_text: 4  Absorption spectra of TCs and (a) emission and (b) excitation spectra of BUT-178 and BUT-179 in solutions of egg extracts.

elements.content: It should be pointed out that reusability is an important property for fluorescence sensors. To explore the recyclability of BUT-179, the MOF particles were recollected by centrifugation after the fluorescence detection of TC. Then, the solid was washed with methanol, dried under a vacuum, and redispersed in solutions of egg extracts for the next run of fluorescence detection. After five cycles, the fluorescence quenching efficiency of BUT-179 toward TC remained at ∼96.5% (Figure S19), indicating the excellent sensing performance and recyclability of BUT-179 to detect the TCs in foods in complicated chemical backgrounds.
elements.clean_text:
Cycling Tests

It should be pointed out that reusability is an important property for fluorescence sensors. To explore the recyclability of BUT-179, the MOF particles were recollected by centrifugation after the fluorescence detection of TC. Then, the solid was washed with methanol, dried under a vacuum, and redispersed in solutions of egg extracts for the next run of fluorescence detection. After five cycles, the fluorescence quenching efficiency of BUT-179 toward TC remained at ~96.5% (Figure S19), indicating the excellent sensing performance and recyclability of BUT-179 to detect the TCs in foods in complicated chemical backgrounds.

elements.content: In this work, two Al MOFs, namely, BUT-178 and BUT-179, were synthesized. They exhibited good chemical stability and attractive fluorescence properties. These two MOFs can effectively detect tetracycline antibiotics with LODs at the nanomolar level, even with the interference of different inorganic salts and the complicated chemical background of eggs. This demonstrated the excellent application potential of MOFs for food safety, especially the fluorescence detection of antibiotics in foods. The structure–performance relationship of these MOFs in the detection of tetracycline antibiotics was also deeply explored and analyzed. We hope our studies can provide insight for researchers and facilitate the further development of MOFs for fluorescence sensing.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In this work, two Al MOFs, namely, BUT-178 and BUT-179, were synthesized. They exhibited good chemical stability and attractive fluorescence properties. These two MOFs can effectively detect tetracycline antibiotics with LODs at the nanomolar level, even with the interference of different inorganic salts and the complicated chemical background of eggs. This demonstrated the excellent application potential of MOFs for food safety, especially the fluorescence detection of antibiotics in foods. The structure-performance relationship of these MOFs in the detection of tetracycline antibiotics was also deeply explored and analyzed. We hope our studies can provide insight for researchers and facilitate the further development of MOFs for fluorescence sensing.

cln_elements.content:
The detailed synthesis steps of H3CTFTA and H3CTCTA are provided in Supporting Information.

Synthesis of BUT-178

Al­(NO3)3·9H2O (50 mg, 0.13 mmol), H3CTFTA (50 mg, 0.11 mmol), formic acid (4.5 mL), and 10 mL of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) were mixed and ultrasonicated in a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. Then, the sealed autoclave was heated at 180 °C for 10 h. After being cooled to room temperature, the resulting white powder was collected, washed with DMF and methanol, and then dried in air [50 mg, 74% yield based on Al­(NO3)3·9H2O].

Synthesis of BUT-179

Al­(NO3)3·9H2O (50 mg, 0.13 mmol), H3CTCTA (50 mg, 0.095 mmol), formic acid (4.5 mL), and 10 mL of DMF were mixed and ultrasonicated in a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. Then, the sealed autoclave was heated at 180 °C for 10 h. After being cooled to room temperature, the resulting white powder was collected, washed with DMF and methanol, and then dried in air [54 mg, 75% yield based on Al­(NO3)3·9H2O].
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of the Ligands

The detailed synthesis steps of H3CTFTA and H3CTCTA are provided in Supporting Information.

Synthesis of BUT-178

Al(NO3)3⋅9H2O (50 mg, 0.13 mmol), H3CTFTA (50 mg, 0.11 mmol), formic acid (4.5 mL), and 10 mL of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) were mixed and ultrasonicated in a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. Then, the sealed autoclave was heated at 180 °C for 10 h. After being cooled to room temperature, the resulting white powder was collected, washed with DMF and methanol, and then dried in air [50 mg, 74% yield based on Al(NO3)3⋅9H2O].

Synthesis of BUT-179

Al(NO3)3⋅9H2O (50 mg, 0.13 mmol), H3CTCTA (50 mg, 0.095 mmol), formic acid (4.5 mL), and 10 mL of DMF were mixed and ultrasonicated in a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. Then, the sealed autoclave was heated at 180 °C for 10 h. After being cooled to room temperature, the resulting white powder was collected, washed with DMF and methanol, and then dried in air [54 mg, 75% yield based on Al(NO3)3⋅9H2O].

cln_elements.content: As shown in panels a and b of , the PXRD patterns of BUT-178 and BUT-179, respectively, are consistent with those of the pristine samples after their treatment with water, dilute acid (pH = 2), and base (pH = 10) solutions for 24 h, indicating the good stability of these two MOFs. As shown in c, the N2 adsorption isotherms of these two MOFs exhibit type I adsorption behavior. The N2 uptake levels of BUT-178 and BUT-179 are ∼478 and ∼466 cm3 (STP) g–1, respectively, and the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface areas are ∼1370 and ∼1443 m2/g, respectively. The pore sizes of BUT-178 and BUT-179 are estimated to be ∼11.5 and ∼11.9 Å, respectively, which are calculated by the density functional theory (DFT) method (Figure S3). These pores should be large enough to accommodate TC molecules, which was further confirmed by the adsorption tests of TCs in these two MOFs (Figure S18). The large channel sizes of BUT-178 and BUT-179 could make the fluorophores on the inner surface areas accessible to TCs and improve the sensitivity of the MOFs to these analytes. The TGA curves showed that the decomposition temperatures of BUT-178 and BUT-179 are >400 °C (Figure S4), demonstrating the high thermal stability of these two MOFs.
cln_elements.clean_text: As shown in panels a and b of , the PXRD patterns of BUT-178 and BUT-179, respectively, are consistent with those of the pristine samples after their treatment with water, dilute acid (pH = 2), and base (pH = 10) solutions for 24 h, indicating the good stability of these two MOFs. As shown in c, the N2 adsorption isotherms of these two MOFs exhibit type I adsorption behavior. The N2 uptake levels of BUT-178 and BUT-179 are ~478 and ~466 cm3 (STP) g-1, respectively, and the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface areas are ~1370 and ~1443 m2/g, respectively. The pore sizes of BUT-178 and BUT-179 are estimated to be ~11.5 and ~11.9 Å, respectively, which are calculated by the density functional theory (DFT) method (Figure S3). These pores should be large enough to accommodate TC molecules, which was further confirmed by the adsorption tests of TCs in these two MOFs (Figure S18). The large channel sizes of BUT-178 and BUT-179 could make the fluorophores on the inner surface areas accessible to TCs and improve the sensitivity of the MOFs to these analytes. The TGA curves showed that the decomposition temperatures of BUT-178 and BUT-179 are >400 °C (Figure S4), demonstrating the high thermal stability of these two MOFs.

metadata.title:
Stable Metal–Organic Frameworks for Fluorescent
Detection of Tetracycline Antibiotics
